div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK andamp; SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN andamp; Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. andamp; O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK andamp; SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Turks and Germans
div.p: We gather that there are no German officers at Akaba, and should like to remind our correspondent who questione us and our readers on this point, that the number of German officers employed in the Turkish army is very small, and that the Ottoman Government has never given any high comman in the field to offiers of foreign armies since the Russo-Turkish was General von der Goltz and other distinguished German officers have been members of teh General Staff and in that capacity have drawn up plans of campaign, schemes for mobilisation, and proposals for strategic railways, which ahve been adopted or pigeon-holed according to the humour of their employers. But their functions have been almost entirely advisoray and their advice has often been followed. If a large number of Geramn officers held executive commands in the Ottoman army that would doubtless be an even more formidable opponent than it now is, but it is doubtful whether, pace Major von Bruchausen, the Padishah will choose to fall in with all the suggestions that Berlin has to offer. In our opinion, the Turkish Governement has acted on its own initiative in the Akaba affair, as it acted last year on the Aden frontier. It does not wish to quarrel with Egyot and Great Britain, but it cannot resist the opportunity of trying to extend its boundaries by a few square miles, even though they consist of "very light soil."

div.head: Cairo School Strikes
div.p: The pupils of the School of Law have struck, and we are threatened, so it is stated with strikes by pupils of the School of Medicine and the Polytechnic, who appear anxious to risk their careers over questions that concern them most remotely, if at all. Meantime, the Governemnt has declared that the courses at the Law School will not reopen till Saturday next, and that if the strikers continue to be defiant they will be exlcuded for good from the School of Law, which will then be closed to await the arrival of a newer and wiser generation. The complaints of the pupils will, we are sure, be examined by the Governement if properly and respectfully brought before the authorities. General strikes by persons of teh strike us as being silly parodies of what were very unpleasant realities in Russia.

div.head: The Akaba Intrigue. The Turkish Version. Reasons For Turkey's Action.
div.p: According to th« Tnrkisb version, of the Akaba affair, wbi h I »'cho with all uecessary reserve,when the matter was mentioned to the Khedive his H ghness professed* his complete ignorance of the incident. \

The Turkish apology, that the yr,usha>hi of the battalion had mis-speD hi* written orders is on a par with the aforesaid version ; exoei t that it is ingenious. It is a method that the Bawab-Aali often employs in conrexion with doonments legalizing property belonging, say, to some unhappy rayah. Bnt applied to diplomacy, it is not so effectual in concealing frand. Moreover, precedent on the borders of Aden and, recently, of Pers;a, tend to show that Turkey's policy regarding international landmarks is a trifle hazy.

The incident has raised considerable comment. at d there is nothing else but 'he oocnpa tion of Akaba by Turks baing talked aboat.the Stambonl public being totally oblivions of the faot that the said port, of Salomonic fame, has had a Turki-h garrison sine? the ratification of the Firman of Wij, and that it is Tabah, an insignificant townlet, 8 miles to the we-t of the line of de marcation, which has been ho onred by the pre-ence of a century of the Soltan's military 'atterdemalions. Perhaps ignorance is bliss when international landmarks are concerned.

However, it is nevertheless interesting to determine why Turkey f-hould be so provocative just now. Some say that the intrigue is a oonnter-move to the opening of Port Sudan, which will increase Arglo-Egyptian inflaenoe on the Red Sea. Others that she seeks an ont- po^ on the Sinaitio Peninsnla for Akaba. whose strategical value will be greatly enhanced with the completion of the H djie Railway. While the third hypothecs, which I prefer, is that Turkey has done this to secure some con oesBioti against her eventual withdrawal from territory which she describes as being under the private administration of the Khedive.
(FROM OUR COR*ESPONDENNT).
Pera, February 20.

The CO' fl ct between England at d the Porte regarding the ; kaba territory is taking a very 8*riot8 torn. E iglai d has sent a Note to Tor- y intimating a naval demonstration in the Red Sea, in front of the Sinai Peninsula. The Note was handed to the Porte on the 12th inst. The Porte still rejects the delimitation of frontiers at the point of Akaba, between Egypt and Syria, which is a«ked for by E gland. In his last interview with Sir Nioholas O'Oonor, British Ambassador, Te»fik Pachs, Minister for Foreign Aff rirs, is said to have declined to enter into any discns8:on, on the ground that there was not even any need to consider the question, Syria and Egypt forming an integral pvrt of the Ottoman Empire. The Turkish population here is g eatly exoited over the conflict between the Porte and Great Britain.

He dismissed the m ndac'Ous assert on that England hali «;\ fulfilled her promises at the olose if the wur. Ho advocated ultimate complete self- government arid recommended a gradual process of contented industrial development,whioh was neoessary to the stability of Sooth Africa. div.head: Notes from Suakin.
Officer's Sad End. Thrown And killed by His Horse.
div.p: It is with great regret that I have to report the dea'h of Mnlazim Awal Mohamed Tewfik, Staff Officer Suakin District, which *ook place yesterday morning as the result of an accident. Deceased fell off his horse while exercising himself for the raoes which were to have taken place ye-terday afternoon. While galloping about 100 yards his horse stambled and threw his rider. The offioer fell on his head, crushing hisskoll, and the horse rolled over him. Medical aid wa8atonoe forthcoming but proved useless He expired abont half an hour after the accident. Mohamed Tewfik was a young and promis ing officer and muoh beloved by everyone who knew him, more especially by his chiefs. The funeral took place abont 3 p.m. yesterday and was well attended by all the military and oivil Government » ffioials, he merchants, and bank agents, the 6 h Battalion E A. aBd polioe furnishing gnarda of honour.
The race* have been indefinitely postponed dog to thia sad acoideut.

div.head: Egyptian Cotton in Scinde.
div.p: Frequent attempts have been made to cultivate Egyptian CDtton in Soinde, and at last a measure ot success seems to have crown ed the persevering efforts that have been put forward in this direction.

The Bombay Department of Agricultore has reported that the experimental stage is past, and that there is a fair prospect of a yield pome 100,000 bales in the course of a few yearp. The most tu^oessfnl varieties so far are he Ahassi and the Mitsffiffi It is suggested that the introduction iff Egyptian cotton int lnd;a may h*ve a stimnlating effect, on th prodnotio* of finer Counts of y»rns bv In ian mills. O her mail npwp from I"dia is > ot re aspnring In various localities the symptoms of f m'ne are ominous, and the numbers in receipt f relief are increasing. The provinces Bengal, Eastern Bengal, and A*sam andBunnah are said to be so far unaffected by scarcity,

div.head: Port Said Notes. Russian Cruisers. Continual Presence in Port.
div.p: The Rassian orniser Bogatyr left here after the arrival of the Rosaia and Gromoboi. Seeing the Rossia recalls the sinking of the Kinshic Maru, the ill-fated Japanese transport, which was snnk by a torpedo from the Rossia. Those who were not killed or drowned were captured by the Russians.

Port Said is now quite aconstomed to the prepence of Russian warships and it seems quite natural to h*ve at least one in port. In some ca es it is like meeting an old acquaintance as some of the ships, DOW returning home, passed through bere on their way to battle and their prospects were folly discussed at the time.
Official visits have been exchanged between H.E. the Governor and Vice-A lmiral Jessen. who is in command c f the Rosaia and Gromoboi, which vessels left on Saturday af ernoon for Liban.
Football,

Last Friday there was a match (A sociation) between Port Said and H.M.S. Minerva, and Saturday a game of Rugby was played between the same teams. Port Said won on Friday, but the Minerva got the honoars on Saturday by a very small margin. If the Port Said team oonld have a ii t'e more practice it would Dot be an easy matter to beat them, as there are some very good players here, and better combination, than now exists, would result in onr having quite a formidable side. French Belli.

A very 8Q0ce*sfol bail was given at the French Club on Saturday evening and it must be regarded as one of the best this season. Dancing was preceded by a cunp'e of ve*y amusing sketches called Monsieur Badin and La Gtammaire, both ot which were extremely well aoted hefote very large andieuce. quite a number of people having oome from Iamiilia to swell the gay throng. It was not until after midnight that the first danoe of a long programme commenced. The rooms of the olob had been most tastefully decorated and much credit for the success ot the ball most be given to the persons responsible for thepe arrangements. Many of the Englieh residents were present, also some naval officers from the Minerva, which added to the general good effect The offioial ball at the French Clnb always the event of the season, but it was remarked that previous efforts had bean •iite eclipsed this time

div.head: Prince D'ARENBERG SURPRISED.
div.p: W* coll the following from oor bright oon temporary, "The Globe Trotter," of Nairobi, edited by Mr. D.G. LoDgworth :—

AmoDgst people of discernment and good sound judgment there is no diversity of opinion in relation to the future of this country. Prince d'Arenberg, the distinguished ohairmin of the Saez Canal Co., at the conclusion of bis visit, and in ihe course of a five-minute interview, nxpres^ed himself as being overjoyed with the sights and soenes of British Ev*t Africa. As I, with my nsnal ardour, enthused over the big game he po'itely informed me that that was not our only asset by any means. In all parts of the country, said he, natare had developed to such an extent that with oatstretched arms she beseeohed the coming of man to complete her effort. And they will oome, and I shall oome, and perhaps for something more than pleasure. I am oonfi lent the development of this protectorate will/ without the shadow of a doubt, increase the receipts of the 8uez Canal, and you can rest assured the "G'obe Trotter" will have a spoke in the wheel of development." With this he bade a ha>ty goo 1-bye and was off for Mombasa, where he departs for gay Cairo by the Austrian Lloyd.

M. Revoilbas handed over to Herr Raduwitz a note declaring that Fra'noe considers her propoeids in DO way assail the commercial and eoonomiC equality, and is of opinion that they should be diaoussed by t^e Conference. 'Reuter)

div.head: CRICKET AT MENA. LADIES V. GENTLEMEN
div.p: On Saturday a'nov.el cricket matoh was played at Me ia H)ose Hotel betw en team of ladies versus gentlemen. The ladies were captained by Mies Hudson, Mr. Ganzaui being the captain of the. gentlemen eleven. The ladies wo*n the toss and went in first. Miss Hodgson and Mtss Hill were the first , to bat aed gave Rn exhibition of excellent cricket.
The fir.-it-ntmed. hitting freely, made 35 runs before she *3»Jbowlef, Miss Hill, who played a steady, cautious game, making 23. * The ladies'.team made in all 65-ruDB.
The gentlemen, following on, were rather unfortunate at the start, four players being bowled io rapid succession/^ Eventually Mr.
Wyard and Mr. Ganzoni settled down and took tfie stihg oat of the buwlirtg. In the end the gentlemen eleven, who were patting and fielding left handed,/won a keenly oontested match by shout 10 runs.
Tent* wore ereoted in the pleasant hotel grounds, where tea was served to the players and onlookers, and as the day was fine every body enjoyed his or herself to their heart's content.

div.head: Prospectus
div.p: The Compsny has bean formed-far the -purpose of [inter alia) carrying on business as Engineers. Contractors and Builders, aud the undertaking of irrigation, railway, oanal, marine sewage, and qonstraotional engineering, aud\pablio works of all kinds.

In consequence of the growth of the tr«td$ and the increase of the wealth in Egypt, and the consequent raising of the standard of living among all classes, and the steady inorease in the-population, the bailding industry in Egypt has been extraprdioarilymotive within recent years; and it is reasonable to sppose that the activity will be at least well maintaned, if not increased; in the future. Engineering and, building operations of all kinds are in progress throughout the country. Large sums of money are to be expended on public works. Private houses, flats and offices are on all sides being erected, and the demand for such buldings is ever increasing.
The following is an extract from the note by the Financial Advisor on the Budget for 1906:--

• Roughly apealtiug, it- may bo said that Egypt is actually spending troin L.E. 300,0X1 to L. E. 400,000 Annually on public buildings ; not, I think, an extravagant sum, haying toward to the revenue of the country and the fact that everything has to be provided ab initio, hospitals, post offices, prisomiTasydums, schools, police stations, to icy nothing ot Gouvernorats, and other Government buildings of practically every description. \ •
"Of course is the above figures are not inoliiaed groat works of publio utility of a remunerative nature, which are charged to Reserve Fund." 1 , t

With the working capital at its command, the Company will be in a position to take full advantage of the increasing prosperity of the country, and to undertake engineering and building contracts of the largest kind. Hitherto it has been found that where any works of magnitude have beon executed in Egypt, the preponderance of oontraots has bean seoUred by European firms. As regards the erection of buildings, as distinguished from other works, the Company will be in the favourable position of being able to complete them from basement to roof, including their equipment throughout with eleotrioal and sanitary appliances ; thus the profits on minor contracts can be secured to the Company. There is a great demand for small residential houses in Cviro aud Alexandria, and a wide field is open to the Company to ereot small houses in suitable localities, according to the plans aud requirements of purchasers, and to have the cost of erection seoured by Mortgages payable in instalments, with the usual interest thereon, extending over a period to suit the convenience of clients. .

The Company will in the first instanoe acquire aud amalgamate the businesses carried on by the well-known firms of Engineers, Contractors and Builders, Messrs. MoClure Dorling, of Alexandria, and Messrs. Q. L. Pezzi and Co., of Cairo and Alexandria. Both firms are'highly respected, and have been entrusted with numerous important oontraots I by-'pamongaj . others—the Egyptian Government, H. H. The Khedive, the British Government, the Egyptian State Railways Administration, the Prisons
Department, the Qaan^ntine
Board, the British Sihools, the Alexandria Water Company, eta,.etc.

Messrs. G.L, Pezzi and Co., who have been eatab'ished since 1865^ in addition to their business as Contractors and Builders, carry on the lucrative basiueis of supplying the building trade with paiats, papers, and other bailding materials and requisite*.

The immediate vendors to aud promoters of the Company are Messrs. Barclay, Hinks- A Co., of Cairo (hereinifeer called "the Vendors"), who^iave agreed to acquire the said businesses from-their respective proprietors with a view to the re-sale thereof to the Company at a profit, the particulars of which appear from the statements hereiuafrer contained. The proprietors, Mr. T. MoClure, Mr. S. Dorling, and Mr. G. L P»zzi. who will b9 the first Managing Direotors of the Company, show their confidence in the Company's fatnre, not only by taking six-serenths of their proportion of the purchase price, other than the valnation of the stook and plant, entirely in fnllv paid shares, bat they have also agreed, by the undermentioned Agreements (4) and (6; that daring the first five years their salaries as Managing Direotors* shall not be payable in any year in which the Company shall not have earnei profits saffioieut to pay a dividend of 7 per oent. on the initial paid-up o«pital, and have further agreed to retain a holding of 10 000 shares daring their term of 1 foots, and to depout the oertifioates of saoh shares with the Company.

Both basinesres will bo taken over by the Company as going oonobrns as from the 1st day *of October, 1905. and the Company will have the benefit of all. profit realised from that date. The property to be transferred ti the Company will indade, besides the goodwills of the twi bminsssiR, the benefit of all pending oontraots, the benefit of the exi-itiDg agreements fir the hnsiueis premises, the book debts from the 1st Ootober, 1905, and the offioe farmtare, fixtures and fittings.

The purchase price for the sale of the paid goodwills, the pending oontraots, the agreements for tenancy of tha business premises, book debts, offioe furniture, fixtures and fittings has been fixed by the under-meutione i Agreement 1 at £10,000. ITie 8tock-in4ra.de'. plant and appliances will be purchased at a valuation'. The. Vendors have agreed to pay the preliminary expenses of the Company down to the first general allotment of shares other than Brokerage, stamps on Share Warrants, and stamp aaty on' the Sale Agreement. 8aoh preliminary expenses are estimated at £2,500. . The value of the goodwills is fixed at £30.000. The Vendors have also agreed in consideration ot the farther payment of* £6,000 in oash to Rubreribe or procure subscriptions for 7\000 shares in the Company ; 12,0 )0 of these shareR have been subscribed for by the Memorandum of Association. The said aminnts payable to th« Vendors, namely £16 001 altogether,, will be paid and satisfied as te £25,000 by the allotment of-25,00;) shares and the baLnoe of £21,000 in oash.

div.head: Management
div.p: The Company will h .ve the a 1 vantage of the exnert services of Mr. Thomas MoClnre, Mr. Stanley Darling and Mr. G. L Pezzi. who have consented to aot as Managing Directors for a period of five years at a nalary of £700 per annum eaoh, payable only as above stated, after profits have been earned sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 per oent. off the original capital ... - - of.the Company. Messrs. McClure, Dorling and Pezzi have all been in Egypt a great number M 11 J I L * „ °;,year^ dar,nK which time they have been engaged in engineering and building contracts of V M. Mendelsohn, M. all kinds, and have acquired an exceptional knowledge of the peculiar and speoial requirements ( of the engineering and building industry of that country.

div.head: Egyptian Art. Conscious OR Scholastic. Prof. Petrie's Second Lecture.
div.p: Prof. Flinders Petrie gave the second of his leotnrea on Egyptian Art at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, yesterday afternoon. The snbjeot was that of the age of Conscions or S.hdastio Art in the Xllth and XVIIIth dynasties. Alter the decay of the art of the pyramid builders, which continued till the me of the Xlth dynasty, a new feeling arose based on oarefal study and restrained expression. The statuary is rather hard and wiry but vigorous : the relief sculpture is low and fall of delicate detail in the surface*. In the Xllth dynasty this became more businesslike in the handling of it, but at the same time formalised. The excellence in taMe and gradual decline during the Xllth dynasty is well shewn by the splendid inlaid pectorals from Dahshur in the Cairo Museum. In the XHIth dynasty the work was still pood, and thesoulpture well maintained; but the style is weak and timid. The question of whether we have any Hyksos portraits is very doubtful ; the figures with names of those kings may be all la*e appropriations of older works and certainly their style has no affinity with what came before or after. In the XVIIIth dynasty, very stiff and formal work prevailed at first, bat gradually softened and became more life like under the Thothme* kings So far, the old traditions of the Xllth dynasty had been carried on. Bat the immense infl lencss of Syria, brought in by the conquests of Thothmes III., revolutionised Egyptian taste : and soon after the powerful style of prehistoric Greece led to new experiments in Egypt. The heads of Queen Thyi are the most vital and refined sculptures known, since the earliest days of the kingdom. The large growth of the middle classes in the XVIIIth dynasty led to a popularity of small artistic objeots of the toilet and genre work. The tastefal and delicate fi ores of girls are a special (development 6f thi* age ; the most perfect of such being the little figure of a negress oirved in ebony, found a few yjars ago at Thebes. The portrait heads carved in wood at this period are also excellent in the modelling and power of character. In drawing, the Egyptians had an extraordinary facility for fine and powerful line. The perfect firmness and artistic truth of the long outlines of limbs, or even whole figures, is unrivalled by any modern school. The be*t examples are seen in Foma of the unfinished tombs and in pome smaller pieces such as a clever figure of a perf inning girl, now at Turin. The new ideas of Syria and Greece had practically killed the native growth of Egypt. After the artistic intoxication of the new wine there was only left an imitation cf the older models. Under Sety I at Abydos is seen a most laborious and highly finished style which has lost all originality. And even the cold gracs of this disappears under IUma8es the Great^of whom there is bat one single work of genius, the black granite figure in Tarin. Henceforward there was nothing but mere imitation, such as has been described in the lecture of last wrek.
Thelectare next week, on Monday at ft p.m., will be on the spontaneous art of the fiueat period, that of the pyramid builders.

div.head: Egyptian Religion
div.p: The lectures delivered by M. Edouard Naville at the College France, under th« Fondation Miohonis, were well attended, and derived peoabar interest from the fact that the lecturer was the first foreigner who h*s been admitted to hold forth within the walls conseoratei to learning by Franois I He choee M his subject the religion of ancient Egypt. His idea of the origin of what we call the Egyptian civilization is that Egypt was inhabited in Nsolitbio times by a white race, the ancestors of the classical Libyans and modern Berbers, who were arohers living in wicker huts, aDd had for domesticated animals fhe deer aud the ««t.ich. These were the "Ancr" or "Teheunu" who as early as the Fifth Dynasty occupied Darfur and Kordofan, and the only hint we get of their religion is contained in the standard panted within the stockade cf the village which perhaps formed the totem of the tribe. The race, in M. Naville's opinion, was corquered by Menes and his followers, who came from Punt, or Somaliland, by way ot South Arabia and Abyssinia. He does not think that the culture of the conqaerore owed anything to Mesopotamia, but holds that it included writing and building with bricks. As to their religion, each invading tribe had a totem, that of the royal tribe being a falcon, the emblem of Horns, with whom the king was always identified. They also believed in existence of a double or , immaterial counterpart, of whioh the fan carried behind the monarch was the emblem and even under the Thinite dynasties tbeir religion had become anthropomorphio. The lectures frill be published, it is hoped, consecutively in the R*vue del'Histoire des fteli- yrm, where the inaugural one has just appeared, and later will form part of one of the publications of the Masfee Gaimet.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.andamp;O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.andamp;O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.p: Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
5 fr. et 2 fr. 50

div.head:

Pills for the Liver andamp; Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
